subject: Re: [junit] Digest Number 778
msgSnippet: Hear, hear. The goal of Programmer Tests is to for the programmer to: * have tangible evidence of progress * clarify the needs of the design * eat his own dog
messageBody:
Hear, hear.

The goal of Programmer Tests is to for the programmer to:

* have tangible evidence of progress
* clarify the needs of the design
* "eat his own dog food" by being forced to write client code before
writing provider code
* keep focus on small steps
* avoid writing too much code in one flow

I don't see how a dedicated unit tester can make that happen for a
programmer.

What I *can* see is how a dedicated tester can think of tests that the
programmer didn't need to drive the design, or just plain missed.
Still, a dedicated unit tester seems to aim at the wrong spot. A
dedicated integration tester or end-to-end tester seems about right.

I feel appropriately inspired. Let me write the article, then I'll be
back. :)

So said Jeff Tulley on 2/21/2003 --------------------

>How do you do TDD with a separate, independent tester?
> That goes against what TDD is, unless the tester is
>pair programming with the developer.
>
>I do sometimes worry though that my testcode doesn't
>test the boundary cases too well since it is not my
>dedicated job to make the code break. But, with TDD
>my code is 90-100% tested whereas otherwise it would
>be 10% (if that). That is such a marked improvement
>that I think it is well worth it, even without
>independent testing.
>
>---- Lauren Bish wrote: -----
>I should have added that I find it useful to have both
>TDD and Unit
>testing
>that is done by a dedicated unit tester. Not many
>developers have the
>proper
>attitude for testing; testing takes a somewhat
>destructive attitude,
>while
>writing code is a creative process. Also, many
>developers don't have
>the
>aptitude or expertise for testing. This is not a slam
>on developers,
>just a
>recognition that testing and developing (both of which
>I have done) are
>two
>different areas of expertise.
>
